title: Can the Raspberry pi 4 run Mac OS? - Quora

response.answer_text: NO. R Pi 4 runs on a ARM based Broadcomm Processor. Apple's Current line of Mac OS, since they shifted from PPC architecture, runs on Intel's x86_64 based processor. ARM and x86_64 are two entirely different platforms. Apple has indicated that it will be very soon shifting away from Intel and use Apple designed platform based on ARM. Apple's current generation of mobile processors as in iPhone X put Intel's laptop grade processors in lower range to shame. Hence that makes sense. But even when Apple did make the switch, it's unlikely to run on RPi that will be current for that time. Apple's ARM processor will be extremely customized. Also R Pi's processing power is too anemic to run a full fledged desktop OS. Even the version of Windows that runs on it is a lean IOT version .

The Raspberry Pi couldn’t run MacOS, but there’s nothing stopping anyone from compiling a version of Darwin for it. Darwin is the open source heart of the MacOS, based on BSD Unix. X11 Window Manager would graft right on too. It would probably be extremely limited, but the Pi isn’t known for high performance anyway. It would be a good bit of work, for certain, but anything that runs Linux variants, could also alternatively run Darwin. macOS 10.14.5 - Source

Maybe. The upcoming Macs will have ARM processors. The Raspberry Pi also has an ARM processor. So while the functionality may be very limited, there is a possibility that the Raspberry Pi could soon run MacOS and become a hackintosh.

Macos is running on Intel. RPi is ARM. Even if Macos goes ARM, it’s likely their own flavor, and not the RPi. When Might Apple Release an Arm-Based Mac? RPi and Mac have different goals, use cases etc.
